Graphics

Recommendation?

Also do yourself a favor and download the Heroes Unleashed mod from here.

When you're all said and done the game has about 175 coop missions to play. I have no idea how many weapons.
If you want to use a controller I recommend Anti-micro. (https://github.com/Ryochan7/antimicro)

Highly recommend the game for any fan of the tactical FPS.

reviewText:
I played this game when it was released, and I was young and stupid so I died every couple of minutes and got frustrated. Re-installed it in 2006 and oh boy, what a joy it was !

► The graphics don't matter here, it's a 2001 game so you can't expect much but you can set it to high resolutions. The good thing about its graphic engine it's the way in which both the enemies and your team can blend in a huge variety of environments. It is sometimes very hard to tell an enemy from a bush for instance, forcing the player to advance slowly, recon the area with the right team member, use the binoculars or the sniper before assaulting a given objective. Despite its age the game provides you with a great variety of environments starting with open woodlands under clear sky, cities, farming areas at night, snowy mountains, foggy marshes with low visiblity ahead and so on. And if that's not enough for you there's Desert Siege and Island Thunder , the game's two add-ons, adding desert environments ( DUH ) and treacherous jungles. This kind of variety is rarely seen in most tactical shooters , making Ghost Recon a must have for any player who likes the genre.

► The A.I is also great. You may experience some pathfinding problems with some of your squad members ( especially in closed environements such as houses - they sometimes get stuck behind a table or block your way upstairs, which is annoying but it doesn't happen that often , you may even finish the game without having these problems. But then again you can control any of your squad members and get them out of the way. ) The enemies have good reactions when a firefight starts, you will see them splitting up instead of sticking together like magnets or just married couples. They will try to get behind you, they advance a little, they stop for a few moments, they go right, they go left and you cannot predict the path they will take in order to find you and kill you. So hiding behind a rock and waiting for 20 russians to pop in one by one so you can shoot them is a no-no. Even in easy difficulty you'll find it challenging ( especially if it's your first time trying this game ).

► Speaking of challenging, let me say a few words about something I didn't like in this game. You can save your games. Now it might sound stupid but save game options for this genre tend to ruin the experience a little bit. It is way more rewarding to finish a mission without saving your progress, it forces you to think twice before doing something, but if you fail 30 seconds before completing the last objective then it is very frustrating to start it all over again. Saving your progress is good for players who are new to tactical shooters, but the more experienced you get the less help you want to get from the game. And speaking about help, there's a radar at the bottom of the screen telling you if there are enemies around you. It doesn't tell you the number of enemies, the small circle turns red if you're approaching an enemy ( or being approached by it ). It also tells you from which direction the gunshots are coming, which is another small cheat. The problem with these tools is that they are distracting. I sometimes get shot because I spend half a second watching my radar to check the coming direction of the gunshots. Other than that, the HUD is alright, it shows your stance, level of injuries, remaining ammo and weapon used. The remaining ammunition in the magazines is another thing that should have been removed..

► Overall the gameplay is good, simple but effective. You can bring up to six Ghosts to the battle, and assign them to Alpha, Bravo and Charlie squads. This gives room for nice pre-planning, you can therefore create a recon squad equiped with silenced weapons, an assault squad carrying assault rifles ( DUH ) and a sniper squad involving the sniper himself and a teamate to protect his back. This is one example among many you can use before pressing the start button. During the mission, you also have access to a tactical map, which is actually a very basic one offering you the possibility to adopt different behaviours ( Assault - fire at will /// Recon - Don't shoot /// and so on ) . You can assign waypoints to the teams allowing you to coordinate an assault for instance. But then again, careful with that tool, if the squad you're not controlling gets stuck behind a rock... there goes you planning. The map could have been greatly improved but it hasn't been, and that's a shame. Finally, the map menu also shows where your troopers have been injured. Being shot in the leg will make the Ghost move slower or will be forced to walk, whereas  an injured arm will greatly reduce his ability to shoot accurately. The objectives you have to complete stretch from capturing a high profile colonel ( and bring it back to the base - yes, you will have to go all the way back to the insertion area so pay attention more tangos incoming !! ) , blowing up planes, clearing an old castle's courtyard, assaulting a farm and a house, destroying tanks, rescuing NATO soldiers and so on and so forth. The diversity of Ghost Recon is amazing for such an old game !

► It comes with 15 singleplayer missions , which is not that much but if you buy the add-ons you'll have enough for weeks . It also has a multiplayer, which I haven't tried, yet. You can also replay the missions, trying different approaches, using different squad members such as specialists ( you can unlock them by completing side objectives and they are very valuable squad members, they come with higher skills in every domain ( stealth, weapons, command, endurance ). You can upgrade the skills of each Ghost by assigning skill points, earned at the end of each mission. I recommend to upgrade the stealth skill as much as possible, I'm just saying...

As a conclusion I would say that this is one of the best tactical shooters out there, and it comes at a cheap price ! What else do you need ?

reviewText:
Ghost Recon still holds up to this day with its non-cumbersome, clean and simple gameplay; yet uncompromising on the tactical side of things. The attention to detail is present in the story, environments and artificial intelligence. Movement and weapon handling feel tactile and make sense. The strategic aspect of this game works well, allowing you to control up to 3 teams in real time. You are able to move them around the environments and adjust their rules of engagement. Enemy A.I. is generally quite smart and is fully capable of eliminating you and your soldiers. They will flank when you least expect it, toss grenades at you, take cover, suppress you, assume better positions, etc.

Most missions in the 15 part sequence of events based around the Cold War truly feel like Special Forces military operations that would occur in reality. Most importantly, you feel involved, and that these missions you are carrying out are only a small contribution to a much larger war effort. Ghost Recon allows you to choose 6 or less Green Berets and/or specialists of various backgrounds (military and ethnic) per mission, either rifleman, support, demolition or sniper. These soldiers can be upgraded upon finishing a mission in the fields of team leadership, weapon control, stealth, and physical endurance. Your A.I. companions generally adapt to situations accordingly, meaning that they will take cover and return fire when necessary, or take a better position. So you don't have to worry about Bravo team on the opposite side of the map.

Now, after a long 10+ years of not playing co-op, I am happy to report that emulating LAN with Hamachi works perfectly and is very, very easy to do. Co-op is great fun (obviously,) and if you cannot handle the wrath of the big boys in Eastern Europe by yourself with a buddy, this game allows 7 A.I. soldiers to aid you in accomplishing your objectives. The two expansion packs both contain an 8 mission campaign, set in their respective locations. These are well worth 5 bucks each and I recommend those as well. Owning the expansions opens up the door to an incredible modding scene, which requires a whole new topic of discussion.

In the end, Ghost Recon hasn't aged a day. The game feels and runs great on modern machines. GR strikes the perfect balance of military simulator and first-person shooter; stripping away the unwieldy mechanics of games such as Operation Flashpoint: Cold War Crisis and ARMA, thus presenting a more polished military tactical shooter (that means fun.) This Tom Clancy series debut remains as intense and immersive as it was when I played it back in 2005. Ghost Recon is authentic, memorable and brilliant. The pinnacle of squad-based battlefield combat. For anyone seeking the real deal, look no further.

Tom Clansy's owned Ghost Recon is a tactical shooter in which you get to control the squad during the mission itself while being able to take control of any of them. Yep, one of realistical tactical, where you die from one shot. It was developed by Red Storm and published in 2001, with being ported onto various consoles in following two years, that are Xbox, GameCube, PS2. And yes, it was made by same people as who made Rainbow Six few years ago, and now they were challenging players by moving action from close-range to long-range open combat. Just like Delta Force, but with fog. And squad tactics.
And yes, it got two more expansion packs that you can buy on Steam as well.

Technically, well, it's actually fine. Sure, game came out before widescreen monitors happened, but engine can support such resolution and allows you to select it from options. Main menu and such will stay as blocky low-resolution 4:3, but as soon as you get into gameplay, it will switch to what you set in options. FOV however will not increase, so people are still chubby.

Not sure about multiplayer. Never got to playing it and Internet browser in the game itself appears as completely empty. No wind, no tumbleweeds. Perhaps server browser is broken. But as far as I am aware, it's dead. And multiplayer was the main positive point of this game, so we are left with less positive single-player.

So, the plot is that in 2008 ultra-super-hyper-nationalists come to power in Russia and are now going to conquer and merge with countries that were part of USSR, starting with finding the way to take on Georgia. Funny how game predicted thatin 2008 there will be conflict with Georgia and Russia, though it wasn't the one where Russia is your everyday demonized baddie. Anyway, you then go and take on various mission to kill people and do objectives, being world's judge. Until you beat final mission. And then get thrown into main menu immeditly. Because screw you, it's realistical tactical lack of ending!

Graphics look kinda nice, I dig the enviroment for sure. Death animations do the job. Lack of gun in view is silly though. Music is fine, just randomly placed in main menu and then sometimes playes when somebody in your team dies.

You got 15 single-players missions to complete and boy, it's not going to be easy. And it wasn't supposed to be easy. As fun as it could be. Anyway, you look at the map which doesn't tell you about verticality, then pick your platoon out of 6 members, that is divided into 3 squads, each having max to 3 people. Mind it, you can order only to whole squad, so better keep specialized people, like sniper, in separate special squad. And Demolition for enemy armor and mission objectives. And Support for having big magazine. But mostly riflemans. You can actually auto-assign people, and game handles it well, even though it never picks anybody from Specialist category. Who are powerful soldiers who may even have unique weapons.
You can get Specialists by completing bonus objective. Where game can screw you up, because it ends mission as soon as either you done all main objective or if killed all enemies if last objective was moving to extraction point. That, and soldiers who died in battle will not reappear. At least they level up between each mission.

And so you will run, you will walk, you will duck and crawl toward enemy, to get into position to shoot them all. Well, mostly running, otherwise you will run out of patience on these big maps covered in fog. And lean around. And notice threat indicator at the bottom of the screen showing red. And snipe enemies. Who will then run toward trees and hide and wait for a moment to lean around and put bulets into your dumb AI teammate. Who you will thankfully kill first. Until you realize that somebody threw grenade and you will be hopelessly trying to switch to each member and micro-manage them to run away. But they all die and so you restart mission as you don't want to have even less soldiers to pick in next mission.

A thing to note, is the way that they did aiming thing. You see, unlike other games, the aiming will drop when you are turning around. Actually, turning around punishes you more than just walking slowly! As a result, it makes flanking more important in this game.

With no planning phase for giving actual order, like in Rainbow Six, Ghost Recon lets you control team during gameplay. Just bring out the map, choose the squad, and click on a map, setting waypoint and where they are supposed to look. Then erase it and do it again, as map UI seems to be unreliably at selecting the team for some reason. But at least I prefer to be able to do it during gameplay. You can also set rules for each team, one for movement: Stop, Move but stop if being supressed, Move at any cost. And rule of engangement: Recon, shoot only if shot back, which is good for ordering troops to get into good position around enemy point. Assault, shoot accurately, sometimes, which is good when on the move and don't know where enemy is. And Supress, which makes them trigger-happy, good when you set them to defend or assault from one position.

And well, now that you wonder what tactics there are, here is what to expect: Always come from unexpected side. If you need to assault inner building, then switch to soldier on one side, kill one enemy, switch to soldier on opposite side, kill another enemy and so on.
As far squad tactics, well, they aren't reliable. But expect to use them to cover your flank. And sometimes to assault base while staying in one position. reviewText:
One of the first Tom Clancy titles that took FPS gameplay to the next level. I recommend this to everyone who seeks a challenging and strategic type of shooter. However it is recommended that beginners play the training mission first.

In Ghost Recon you have to be careful before you take each step. It's like being a soldier in real life, where if you run out in the open you'll get spotted and shot within seconds. Enemies are often equipped with camo suits so they can hide themselves between trees, bushes and dirt. The same realism applies to the damage dealt by weapons, most of the time kills are achieved with 1 shot (except if you hit arms or legs).

Although the game is based on levels, the map design makes it feel almost like a sandbox game. There are always many ways to complete the objectives. Not to mention that the quality of the foliage and nature environment is phenomenal for the date the game came out. There are also different classes and weapon sets that you can choose, which means variety in your playing style. In most games where you choose a class, you can only do that in multiplayer. You can also boost the stats of your soldiers after every mission, which in my opinion makes it a little more balanced because of the AI being challenging.

Definitely recommended.

I played Ghost recon when it first came and was instantly hooked. Since then the development of military FPS have rocketed away from what was – back in 2001 – quite an advanced game. Both the original game and its expansion packs (Desert Siege and Island Thunder) was built around huge maps, the management of a small team of six soldiers and sharp punishment for not thinking tactically and proceeding with some caution. The enemy had a deadly aim, even if their AI wasn’t always on top.

Then came various games like Call of Duty, Battlefield, Ghost recon Future Soldier and Sniper Ghost Warrior, and more work and less time to play made me give away my Ghost Recon Gold collections box to a friend. It was just by pure chance that I earlier this year suddenly discovered that Steam sold the original Ghost Recon with its official expansion packs for “pennies” and I could not resist buying it. It can be a risky business to return to old pleasures; like a movie or a book, you remember from the past, but I found myself enjoying the gameplay as much as I did back in 2001.

reviewText:
In my opinion Rainbow Six 3 improved. This is my favorite tactical shoot hands down, even to this day. I can do nothing but recommend this, even to newbies of the genre. It will be hard to get into, and is by NO MEANS like any of the games succeeding it, this is a true squad based tactical shooter and brutally unforgiving, and I mean more than unforgiving.

So what is it? Ghost Recon (and the accompanying DLC) at its heart is a squad based (six men at once) tactical first person shooter. This means one bullet or so and you die, and the enemy dies. On occasion you may get injured but that is determined by your stats.

The game revolves around four classes. Support, Rifleman, Snipers, and Demolitions. Each with a wide array of weapons to choose from. You will create a squad of six men and utilize these roles before each mission (there are around 12 missions in the base game, and these missions are LONG, not to mention re-playable) after each completed mission (missions consist of various goals, some optional, optional goals earn you specialists which are basically soldiers that come with new weapons and a higher stat average) each surviving (and trust me, you will have alot of men die) soldier will earn one skill point to spend in four fields. How you spend these skills will let Billy Bob BillyboNilly survive longer on the battlefield, and will be what makes you throw your keyboard to the floor when little red riding hood gets ♥♥♥♥ed trying to peek around a corner, oh wait thank god she's injured now lets just crawl behind thi- Susy no!

So yeah, I'm sure you get the point behind that. Now, you may be asking, how does the port hold up after so long? Well actually pretty great! The controls are all rebindable, although some things are a little old this is quite easy to get used to. It supports modern resolutions albeit poorly at times, and the menus are all rendered in a very archaic resolution. Squad management works quite well, and the UI is easy to get used to, as well as the map, so it isn't all bad.

And what about the gameplay? Well as I have mention this is a squad based tactical shooter, you move quite slowly even when sprinting, and you die incredibly quickly, especially when new. You have to plan out everything, this isn't Battlefield or COD, there is no run and gun aspect here, you run you die. Primarily what you will be doing is organizing your squad and dishing out orders, maybe you'll set up a sniper and a support to go up a hill and provide suppression, while a Demolitionist fires rockets up the enemies ♥♥♥ and two rifleman move upwards and breach a house. Maybe this all goes wrong and you aim that rocket wrong killing poor Roger Rabbit and subsequently attracting the enemies to your position, its all part of the plan, and let me state this. You will have so many stories to tell from playing this game, of plans going wrong to pure moments of bliss.

Story sucks don't pay attention to it

Also buy the expansions, they add amazing new content and are done right in so many ways.

Now for what is wrong, the enemy AI is at times unfair, you can peek a corner and just get destroyed and it sucks. The Squad AI does hold up well though, and is actually quite competent! Con number two is that some of the ways you use the explosives are wonky and often may get you killed in the beginning until you get used to them (have no fear they are by no means necessary in alot of missions). And that is really all I can think of, the level and map design is supreme and the missions are hectic and keep you on your feet at all moments of the night. Overall this game is the kingpin in my opinion of tactical shooters.

Still one of the most hardcore and tactical shooters. Runs with no issues on Windows 10.

The graphics and sound still hold up well. The game is showing its age in areas from a gameplay perspective, but never in a way that greatly detracts from the experience provided you can adapt to some of the issues. For example, squad commands are limited and given from an overlay and you can't direct your squad to a position from the first-person view, which is a little clunky. In addition, your squad generally feels like a backup selection of playable characters that tag along with you as opposed to a group of AI you'll feel you can often use tactically and trust to perform without getting themselves killed.

Other issues I had included the way the game occasionally cheap-shots you by spawning a tank or truck full of enemies out of nowhere, which rolls up to your position in complete silence; and whilst the large, open maps still feel unique and fun to play on, you can't climb or step down many hills or cliffs, which tends to limit your tactical ability.

Still, as I said, none of this greatly detracts from the experience as it really never feels hugely misaligned with the gameplay--they're more just indications of the game's age. The atmosphere and intensity remains intact. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend a playthrough if you're into tactical shooters.

reviewText:
The bottom line is that the original Ghost Recon remains as the best release in the entire series.

The game shines in the non-linear, non-restrictive gameplay that has plagued many linear corridor shooters (to include Ghost Recon Future Soldier). Players have a map, and a team of men, and must apply critical thinking through mission analysis in order to be successful.

The game also has an outstanding damage model that still outshines most shooters; A single 5.56mm round will kill, and players can sustain arm and leg wounds that affect their ability to shoot and move. Third person animations also reflect player damage in the form of limping and visible blood stains and gunshot wounds.

There is also an RPG-like system that allows players to develop their Ghosts and apply personal attributes that will improve their performance.

reviewText:
Years years ago, when I finally had my second computer (my first computer, that I got back when I had 5 years, was just obsolete at that point), this is one of the games that came with it. And let me tell you, even back then I knew this was a great game. Does it hold up for today's standards though, after SO MANY YEARS? Well, yes. You can keep reading, and find out why, but as usual on my reviews, I'll start with the bad stuff:

Sadly, the worst part of the game is also the best part of it: The difficulty. Have you played other FPS games? Back then, FPS games were all about being a generic American hero who could take 9001 bullets, carry over 10 guns at the same time, jump insane distances, run like hell non-stop, and basically be a God. This game was one of those that stopped and did the complete opposite. Enemies die in one or two shots, yeah. And so do yourself. Gameplay is slow, enemies at times come out of nowhere, you get the idea. While people like me would love this, I can tell a lot of people would NOT enjoy it's difficulty at all.

Another thing that might turn people away are the graphics. Now, while I don't really hate them, the game has not aged well at all on that matter. Leaving how pretty the game is, there seems to be some weird bugs and glitches related to the game and graphics: At times stuff can be seen weirdly clear through the fog, both enemies and allies trying to shoot people through walls, parts of enemies clipping through solid objects and more of the same kind of stuff. Also, while the gameplay can be played in Widescreen, which surprises me for a game this old, the menus run in 800x600, which is just weird.

The last thing I will complain about this is the AI. Everyone seems to be a bit... Stupid. At times soldiers act in really weird ways, and the enemies can also act in unpredictable r#tarded ways as well. Infact, in the 4 missions I've played so far, I've also gotten teamkilled by my teammates 3 times, because they seem to enjoy using the grenade launchers at close-range. And I'm not even joking with that, the AI really loves that weapon.

All of that being said, what you have left is a gem that still packs more and better Gameplay than 70€ sh#ts we get today. Just to remind you, this is a game that got close to KILL CALL OF DUTY AND MEDAL OF HONOR (which killed itself anyway, rofl). It's all about being stealthy, taking enemies properly. You have a squad of 6 soldiers, which you can control and jump from one to other if you feel like changing. There are also 4 kind of soldiers, without counting the Specialists, which you unlock by winning missions. You're given liberty to do the missions as you please. Wanna rush them with machine-guns, or rather snipe them one after another? SUIT YOURSELF!

There's also multiplayer... But well, it's an old game. Good luck finding people to play with. I played once a few years ago with a friend using Hamachi, and it was indeed insanely fun. If you do find people, then you'll enjoy it. People call this Like the Dark Souls of FPS"

reviewText: Ghost Recon is one of the all time classics of the tactical FPS genre. I have played this game many times over since the early 2000s, and it still plays great. Even if the graphics are slightly dated, the game play more than makes up for it. You have to be smart and tactical in your approach to combat and as such this game is a rarity nowadays. If you don’t plan the approach, more often than not, you will be spotted and taken out. This is also an open map style game so you can achieve your objectives from many angles, only helping its tactical appeal. Another interesting aspect is the ‘command map’ in which you can control other squads and have them move as a separate entity. Each squad has maximum of three members and you can have 3 squads but a max of 6 total characters. Each of these characters is playable through selecting him or her in the command interface.\n\nThis game truly is the pinnacle of the genre so if you’re not hung up on graphics but are interested in realistic combat, then this is definitely the game for you.
